We worked around the clock. But despite the many frustrating setbacks, the team I have been blessed to work with never gave up. Mariam and the kids have been through so much, literally looking death in the face multiple times, including again today, but they never gave up either.

Mariam had gone to visit her parents for the first time with the kids and became trapped in Kabul when the Taliban overran the city. We left two weeks ago today to get her, the children, and others out.

But that doesn’t mean we’re leaving behind the thousands of union workers who have worked on the pipeline to put food on the table.

We need to pass a Green New Deal to make our unions the backbone of tackling our climate crisis.

Police have used torture devices, chemical agents, and low-flying aircraft to assault protesters demonstrating for environmental justice.
 
Law enforcement are doing the bidding of Enbridge, not the people.

This is about protester rights. 
 
More than 800 Water Protectors have been arrested by a law enforcement agency that has received $2+ million from Enbridge. 

That is unjust. That is unacceptable. That will not be tolerated.

This is about environmental justice.
 
The pipeline directly violates the treaty rights of the Anishinaabe by endangering their areas of hunting, fishing, cultivation, and culture. It will disproportionately impact low-income communities with dirty water and cancerous chemicals.

Enbridge, the company building this pipeline, has an incredibly reckless history. They are responsible for more than 800 spills between 1999 and 2010 — including the largest inland oil spill in US history.
 
It is completely irresponsible to allow them to expand their capacity.

The Line 3 replacement would nearly double the volume of tar sands crude oil — the dirtiest fossil fuel on the planet — coming through the pipeline.
 
A spill could devastate the entire Mississippi River.
 
I spent the weekend visiting the site. 

Here are my takeaways. 🧵

Unionized workers earn 11% more than their counterparts without union representation. Union workers also have better health benefits and access to paid sick leave on average. It's time to allow more workers to have a say in their workplace and pass the PRO Act.

Other provisions of the PRO Act would put an end to the gig economy exploitation of the independent contractor loophole. This loophole allows Lyft and Uber to pay fewer taxes, prevent their workers from unionizing and dodge labor protections.

Currently, when corporations like Amazon are found in violation of labor law they face no punishment. The PRO Act would allow the NLRB to fine these corporations, levying increasingly heavy fines for repeat offenders, ending illegal union-busting and protecting workers’ rights.

The PRO Act is the boldest piece of pro-worker legislation in 80 years. On Labor Day it is important to support workers and discuss this vital legislation. I am a cosponsor of the PRO Act which will empower workers and protect their right to organize.
